column5: Web Components + JS/Polymer inside Chrome-based browsers
column8: Web client built on WebRTC + JS, backend Angular/React

column5: Adaptive QUIC + WebRTC congestion control, Lyra codec for ultra low bandwidth ([Wikipedia][4])
column6: Dynamic bitrate (~2.6 Mbps for group HD) with adaptive fallback
column7: Adaptive (~1–2 Mbps per stream) WebRTC based
column16: All support dynamic bitrate auto-adjustment based on network quality

column5: Up to 1080p HD on premium; auto‑adaptive ([Wikipedia][4], [medium.com][5])
column6: Up to 720p default; 1080p with Business/Enterprise plans
column7: Up to 1080p, auto-adjust based on client CPU
column16: Resolution depends on plan and endpoint capability

column5: VP8, VP9, H.264; Opus; Lyra for voice fallback in low bandwidth ([Wikipedia][4])
column7: SILK, G.722, H.264 audio via Teams infrastructure
column8: H.264, Opus codecs used across media
column16: Standard WebRTC codec support; advanced voice codecs for low bandwidth

column5: DTLS‑SRTP and TLS (1.2/1.3); limited E2EE for Workspace Enterprise ([Wikipedia][4])
column6: TLS 1.2+ for signaling; AES‑256 GCM for media; optional E2EE (with reduced features) ([Back4App Blog][3], [developers.zoom.us][6])
column7: Mutual TLS signaling; AES‑256 GCM over SRTP for media
column8: TLS + SRTP (AES‑128/256); E2EE available in hybrid mode
column16: End‑to‑end media encryption varies by platform and tier

column5: Google Meet REST API & Workspace integration endpoints ([Google for Developers][7])
column6: Zoom REST APIs, SDKs, JSON Web Tokens (JWT auth) ([developers.zoom.us][6])
column16: Extensible integrations via public APIs across services

column5: Google‑managed STUN/TURN services; uses QUIC/UDP routing
column6: Zoom's global TURN relays via AWS edges
column8: Cisco TURN/STUN infrastructure for global mediation
column16: All platforms use STUN/TURN; self‑hosting gives control in Jitsi only
